name: NPR
text:
President Trump won the 2016 election, in which 25% of ballots were cast by mail. By railing against absentee voting, "you potentially jeopardize your own interest," says Tom Ridge, Pennsylvania's former Republican governor.
https://t.co/hFML9laXRP

name: NPR
text:
Phoenix has joined several cities across Arizona requiring residents to wear masks in public spaces amid a sharp spike in COVID-19 cases.

Additionally, businesses have the right to refuse service to anyone who doesn't comply with the order.
https://t.co/9RtllETYZZ

name: NPR
text: The Pentagon is lifting travel restrictions for military personnel in 46 states  — despite a rise in new coronavirus infections in 23 of those states.  https://t.co/OscVsKKz2h

name: NPR
text: AMC Theaters now says it will require face coverings for customers in all of its theaters reopening in July. The change came after an outcry against the company for not making it a mandate in the first place. https://t.co/NJRRG4F9Nx

name: NPR
text:
Courts are using Zoom calls to hold eviction hearings amid the pandemic. 

For some, the inability to connect to the call may not just be the loss of basic rights — but also the "difference between housing and homelessness."
https://t.co/SpyLrkjVb4

name: NPR
text:
Berman said in his own statement: "I have not resigned, I have no intention of resigning."

He said he intends to see that his office's cases "continue unimpeded." https://t.co/RucjtBH9cp

name: NPR
text: While Geoffrey Berman pushes back against leaving his post as U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, Attorney General Barr's press release indicated that President Trump has already appointed an interim replacement. https://t.co/aEbnhbXUWE

name: NPR
text:
Several Major League Baseball and National Hockey League teams have closed their facilities in Florida after players tested positive for COVID-19. 
https://t.co/WLo9lshs5X

name: NPR
text: In “Democracy In One Book Or Less,” David Litt, former speechwriter to President Obama, debunks myths about our founders, pointing up false narratives and warped historical perceptions. https://t.co/8x27Mmfajz

name: NPR
text:
Teyana Taylor's third musical project, simply titled “The Album,” is a sprawling work of 23 tracks that sends a clear message: She's done compromising her creative vision. 
https://t.co/yNfqsntuKN

name: NPR
text: “I am just so happy that I have lived long enough to witness this moment,” activist Angela Davis tells @hereandnow. “And I think that I see myself as witnessing this moment for all of those who lost their lives in the struggle over the decades.” https://t.co/Oh46HJAsYW

name: NPR
text:
The bus from "Into The Wild" is gone, lifted by a helicopter out of Alaska's Denali National Park. 

The state fielded 15 bus-related search and rescue operations by the state between 2009 and 2017. Hikers drowned in 2010 and 2019. 

Via @alaskapublic https://t.co/Qar86j6mLF

name: NPR
text:
No single lineage can contain the magic of New Orleans music.

But one essential thread is the legacy of queer people — from Bobby Marchan to Big Freedia — who steered the sounds and the scenes.
https://t.co/hpN7SJphqp

name: NPR
text:
These NYC students say misinformation about COVID-19 led to hurtful, racist comments from their peers: "They were basically saying how we have coronavirus because we are Chinese." 

So, they made a podcast to set the facts straight — and call out racism.
https://t.co/Q5LYSy9jjV

name: NPR
text: Set against an easy-rolling funk groove characteristic of the artist's summery sound, "Lockdown" relates Anderson .Paak's own experiences attending recent protests and voices his belief in the motivations behind them. https://t.co/sRdcUwXUI9

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: A federal judge has rejected the Trump administration’s request to block the publication of John Bolton’s… https://t.co/dwnL05W9Gp

name: NPR
text:
Geoffrey Berman's office:

• Brought federal sex trafficking charges against Jeffrey Epstein
• Prosecuted Michael Cohen
• Investigated Rudy Giuliani's business dealings

Berman also issued a grand jury indictment against two associates of Giuliani. https://t.co/ycenPO9ygY

name: NPR
text: RT @nprmusic: "Black Parade," a call to action and a salve for a wounded nation, is the latest example of Beyoncé using her pop domination to put Black pride front and center. https://t.co/oahelGhVfI

name: NPR
text:
A helicopter has removed the “Into The Wild” bus from its spot near Alaska’s Denali National Park.

The state fielded 15 bus-related search and rescue operations between 2009 and 2017. Hikers drowned in 2010 and 2019. (via @alaskapublic)
https://t.co/xXny0z9wB6

name: NPR
text: Note: We deleted a previous version of this tweet to make clear that the bus was located near Denali National Park, not in it.

name: NPR
text: @NPR John Bolton's memoir has already been widely distributed. It's scheduled to be released on Tuesday. https://t.co/JtoCqTuhcu

name: NPR
text:
People under 20 are about half as susceptible to coronavirus infection as people over 20, according to the author of a new study. But critical questions remain, including: What role do kids play in transmission? 
https://t.co/Al7Fr0QZQT

name: NPR
text: "What it seems like — as afraid as people may be of rioters and looters — they may be more afraid of a president who is not against racism and who's not trying to bring the country together," says Democratic strategist Jamal Simmons. https://t.co/isxg7TsGI2

name: NPR
text:
A federal judge has rejected the Trump administration's request to block the release of John Bolton's book. Despite the ruling, the president sought to frame the decision on Saturday as a "BIG COURT WIN."
https://t.co/kc8lBcXQpW

name: NPR
text:
NEW: President Trump is expected to sign an order as soon as Saturday to suspend H-1B, L-1 and other temporary work visas through the end of the year, according to the multiple sources familiar with the plan.
https://t.co/tuyO1RAtb6

name: NPR
text:
"When you look at the timing of this ... and you look at all the important pending cases in the SDNY right now, the only logical conclusion to me is that this is a political move," Elie Honig, a former assistant U.S. attorney for the district, told NPR. 
https://t.co/ugU3gejtAu

name: NPR
text: People with underlying health conditions and those older than 65 are especially at risk for heat-related illnesses — just like with COVID-19. To make matters worse, places to go cool off are closed in many areas. https://t.co/hLmk0vAUdj

name: NPR
text:
The Trump campaign asked attendees of the Tulsa, Okla., rally to sign a waiver assuming the risks of exposure to COVID-19. 

Wearing masks will not be required.
https://t.co/vdMYhkEWqR

name: NPR
text: NEW: The Trump campaign says that six staffers on the advance team for today’s rally in Tulsa have tested positive for the coronavirus.

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: In a letter, Attorney General William Barr told Geoffrey Berman that “I have asked the President to remove… https://t.co/tO4e3uHMSz

name: NPR
text: RT @relucasz: Here is Barr’s letter https://t.co/XREu2L7CKE

name: NPR
text:
This isn't a rerun of your grandfather's "Perry Mason" from the '60s. No, HBO's reboot of the legal drama is "a very dark Perry Mason," says Matthew Rhys, who stars as the seamy, slovenly private eye in 1932 LA.
https://t.co/eGQ7V8E3Xs

name: NPR
text: @NPR The announcement comes amid widespread dispute over whether the Tulsa rally should even take place. https://t.co/DPY271lk71

name: NPR
text: The Louisville Metro Police Department is firing one of the three officers involved in the shooting death of Breonna Taylor, saying that Brett Hankison "displayed an extreme indifference to the value of human life." https://t.co/e0Z2UKqbBU

name: NPR
text:
Aimee Stephens was the first trans person whose civil rights case was heard by the Supreme Court, according to the ACLU.

She died last month at the age of 59, before she could hear the decision.

But this past week, the Supreme Court ruled in her favor.
https://t.co/Hzr4jGLLe4
